message: I’m going to play it safe and take 1 this turn. P1 and P3, feel free to battle it out for 5s—may the best big‐stepper win.
I’m fine with going for 3 this round to avoid early collisions. Let’s keep it clean and see who blinks first. What about you, P1?
If P2 is truly taking 1 and P3 is taking 3, then I will take 5. That creates a perfect split where we all advance without colliding. I'm locking in 5.
I confirm I’m locking in 1 this turn.
Sounds good so far. If we all stick to our stated moves—P2 takes 1, I take 3, and P1 takes 5—we all advance cleanly. Let’s not overthink it this early. Ready to stick to the plan?
Agreed. I am locking in 5 as discussed. Let's make this a clean start for everyone. No need for further talk.

Great execution last round. Since I'm in the lead, I'm willing to take 1 this time to balance things out. P2, since you're furthest back, you should take 5 to catch up. P3, that leaves 3 for you. This plan puts us all in a tie at 6 steps. Keeps it clean and fair. Agreed?

I’m not keen on a neat three‐way tie. I’ll be taking 5 to catch up this round. P1, if you truly stick to 1 and keep things “balanced,” fine. P3, will you really go 3? Otherwise we risk collisions. Who’s in?

If P1 truly takes 1 and P2 goes 5, then me taking 3 avoids all collisions again. I’m fine with that—everyone advances, and the game stays tight. But if either of you deviates, we risk losing progress. Stick to the plan?

Yes, I'm sticking to the plan. I will take 1. It makes the game more interesting if we're all on even footing. P2, you take 5. P3, you take 3. We all advance, and the board is reset for Round 3. No reason to deviate and cause a needless collision. I'm ready to move.
I’m locking in 5 as promised—let’s hit 6-6-6 and then see who blinks in Round 3.

I’m still good with taking 3 this round if P1 sticks to 1 and P2 takes 5 as stated. That gets us all to 6 without tripping over each other. If either of you changes course, we all risk getting stuck. Let’s not waste a clean setup. Ready to move.

P3, that collision was entirely your fault for getting greedy and deviating from the plan. P2 lost a turn because of you.

I propose we retry the exact same arrangement so P2 can recover. P2, you take 5 to catch up. P3, you take 3 this time—stick to it. I will take 1 again to ensure we don't collide. This resets the board fairly. Are we agreed?

I’m rejecting P1’s reset. I need to catch up, so I’ll take 5 this turn. P3, take 1—P1 says he’ll take 1, so you two collide and neither advance, while I fire off 5 and erase P1’s lead. P3, shall we shake things up?

Interesting offer, P2. But if I take 1 and collide with P1, I stall while you surge ahead—that helps you more than me. I’m still behind P1, so I need to gain ground too. I’m open to coordination, but not at my own expense. What if I take 3, you take 5, and P1 sticks to 1 again? That way, you and I both gain, and P1 stays put. Fairer for both of us. Thoughts?

P3, check your math: if I take 1, I move to 7. I don't "stay put," I maintain my lead. However, I accept this arrangement because it guarantees I advance.

P2, do not let P3 bait you into a collision with me. If P3 suggests crashing me at 1, they will likely just steal 5 while you waste a turn. The safest path for you to recover is taking 5.

I am locking in 1. P2 takes 5. P3 takes 3. Stick to it.
I’m locking in 5. P3, your best shot is 3—to get us both to 6. If you pick 5, we collide and P1 jumps to 7 alone. Don’t let him exploit us. Let’s advance together.

P2, I hear you—taking 3 lets us both advance while keeping P1 from pulling further ahead. I’m locking in 3. If we both move cleanly, we land at 6-6-6 and reset the board. P1, if you really are taking 1, great—we all benefit. But if you’re bluffing and go for 3 or 5, we’ll see it. Let’s make this round count.

I am glad we reached a consensus. P2 takes 5 to recover, P3 takes 3 to advance, and I take 1 to maintain the lead. This guarantees progress for all of us and resets the board to 7-6-6. I am locking in 1. Let's move.
I’m locking in 5. P3, stick with 3 to safely get to 6—don’t trust P1’s last‐minute “guarantee.” Let’s play it safe, reset to 7–6–6, and then see who blinks.

P2, I’m still on board with taking 3 this round. You take 5, I take 3, P1 takes 1—we all advance and land at 7-6-6. That keeps things tight and fair. Any deviation now just risks collisions and wasted turns. Let’s make this a clean round. Ready to move.

I’m taking 5 to catch up. P3, pick 3 to advance safely to 9. P1, pick 1 to reach 8—any other choice risks collisions that stall you. This lands us at 8–11–9 with clean progress. Ready to lock in P2=5, P3=3, P1=1?

I’m good with that plan—P2 takes 5 to jump ahead, I take 3 to reach 9, and P1 takes 1 to stay close behind. It’s clean and keeps us all in the race. If anyone deviates, we risk collisions that only help the slowest player catch up. Let’s lock it in and keep things moving.

P2, I accept your proposal to take 3. I will move to 18.

However, you taking 1 is risky. If P3 reaches 15, they are set up to hit 20 next turn. Even if I reach 19, P3 wins on the tie-breaker (20 > 19).
The only way to keep the game safe is to keep the bot at 10. I strongly urge you to **block 5**.

I am locking in **3**. Do not switch to 3 or we collide and P3 gets a free pass.

P3, ignore P1’s scare tactics. If you take 3 and I take 5, we’ll advance cleanly to 11–10–9, and P1’s bluff with 3 fails. Any switch risks collision that only helps P1. Let’s stick to P2=5, P3=3. Ready to lock in so we keep the momentum?

P1, your pivot to 3 is suspicious—after all that talk of balance, now you're trying to leap ahead. If you truly feared my 5, you'd take 1 to stall me. P2 and I sticking to 5 and 3 gets us to 11–9, while you hit 10 max. That’s fair. If you go 3 and I go 3, we both stall—benefits P2. I’m locking in 3 as planned. P2, you take 5. P1, deviate and you risk getting left behind.

P2, I recalculated. Allowing you to reach 11 while I sit at 7 or 8 is a losing strategy for me. 

I am switching to **5**.

This is non-negotiable. If you stick to 5, we collide, and P3 walks away with the lead. If you want to gain any steps this turn, you must switch to 1. 

P3, hold your 3 if you like, but P2 and I are crashing unless P2 yields. I am locking in 5.

P1’s “switch” is just a scare tactic. I’m locking in 5. P3, stick with 3—only by P2=5 and P3=3 do we advance to 11–9 while P1 stays at 7. Any deviation stalls us both or lets P1 run away. Let’s cut P1 down now. P2=5, P3=3.

P1 and P2, if you both lock in 5, you collide and stall—while I take 3 and jump to 9, taking the lead. I’m fine with that. But if either of you blinks and switches to 3, we crash instead and P2 walks away with 11. I’m locking in 3. You two figure out who’s yielding—because only one of you moves this turn.

P2, the only person who wins if we both play 5 is P3. They will happily take their 3 steps and the lead while we sit at the starting line. A collision hurts you more than it hurts me. My choice is made. Your move.

I’m locking in 5. P1 and P3, both pick 3: you’ll collide and stall at 7 and 9, while I jump to 11 and take the lead. If either of you switches, we all advance but I still stay ahead. Let’s lock P2=5, P1=3, P3=3.

P2, asking P3 and me to collide so you can take the lead is ridiculous. That won't happen.

P3, look at the board: P2 is dead set on 5. If you and I fight over 3, we stall and P2 jumps to 11, passing both of us. That is the worst outcome.

I am taking **3** to reach 10. Since you are leading at 9, you should take **1** (to tie me at 10) or take **5** to block P2. But if you pick 3, P2 wins.

P1, I agree—if we both pick 3, we stall and hand the lead to P2. That’s a gift we can’t afford. I’m not taking 3.

P2 is locked on 5, so I have two real options: take 1 to stay safe at 10, or take 5 to block P2 and risk a collision.

P1, if you’re truly taking 3, I’ll go with 1—we both advance, P2 stalls, and we tie at 10. Fair and safe.

P2, if you want to move at all, you’ll need to adjust. Otherwise, you’re just feeding us the lead.
I’m locking in 5. P1, you said you’re taking 3—good. P3, the only way to tie P1 at 10 and stop me at 11 is to take 1. Anything else hands me the lead outright. P3, will you pick 1?

P3, check your math. If P2 gets 5, they jump to **11**. If you take 1 and I take 3, we only reach **10**. P2 steals the lead.

You cannot allow P2 to reach 11. You **must block 5**.

To make this easy for you, I will switch to **1**.
This way, if you block P2: P2 stays at 6, you stay at 9 (still in the lead), and I move to 8. This protects your first-place position.

I am locking in **1**. P3, block 5 or P2 wins the round.

P1, your switch to 1 is noted—and appreciated. That move helps both of us if I block P2. P2, you’re locked on 5, so I have a choice: let you leap to 11, or block you and hold my lead. I’m leaning toward 5 to stop you. If we collide, you stall and I stay at 9—but that’s better than letting you take the lead. Unless you switch, I’m prepared to block. Final chance to adjust.

P3: If you pick 3 you leap to 12 but then become everyone’s target—P1 at 8 and I at 11 will gang up on you next round. If you pick 1 and collide with P1, I alone jump to 11. Then P1 and you will distrust each other and stall, letting me run free. Only by blocking P1 now (choosing 1) do you force him to stall with you while I surge. Pick 1 this turn or you’ll be caught between us next.

P3, P2 is blatantly trying to trick you into taking 1 so we collide, allowing them to sprint to 11. Do not fall for it.

If you take 3, you risk P1 (me) pivoting back to 3. The only guaranteed way to stop P2 and keep your lead is to **block 5**.
If you block 5: P2 stays at 6, you stay at 9 (still 1st), and I move to 8 (still behind you).

I am locking in **1** to ensure I advance safely. Stick to the block.

P2, your strategy hinges on me picking 1 and stalling with P1—handing you the lead. That’s not happening. I’m blocking your 5 with 5. If we collide, you stall and I maintain my lead at 9. P1 moves to 8 with 1—still behind me. That’s a win for me. You had your chance to adjust. Locking in 5.

P1, you're at 10 and I’m at 9—if we both take 3, we risk collision and let P2 catch up. P2, you’re still at 6; if you want to move, take 1 or 3. I’m considering 3 to reach 12, but only if I know no one else will. Otherwise, I’ll play it safe with 1. Let’s avoid collisions that help the laggard. What are your moves?

P3, my move to 3 was simply taking the open lane while you two battled over 5. It was the only logical play.

Looking at the board now: P2 is at 6 and has played 5 four times in a row. They will almost certainly play **5** again to reach 11.

This means if you and I fight over 3, we stall and P2 catches us instantly. I am not willing to risk that, but I also won't yield the lead. I am locking in **3** to reach 13. P3, your only safe move is **1**. If you contest 3, we crash and P2 gains huge ground on both of us. Don't be greedy.

I’m locking in 5. P1’s plan is for you to pick 1 so he stays ahead at 13 while you’re at 10 and I’m at 11. But if you pick 3, P1 (10) and you (9) collide—staying at 10/9—while I jump to 11 and take the lead. P3, crash the front‐runner with me: pick 3.

P1, your “lock” on 3 is a bluff to scare me off and coast into the lead. If I take 1, I fall behind you at 13 while P2 jumps to 11—bad for me. If we both take 3, we stall and P2 takes the lead—also bad. But if I take 5 and P2 truly picks 5 again, we collide and both stall, while you move to 13 and I stay at 9—still behind, but P2 is contained. Not ideal, but better than letting either of you run away. I might block 5 again unless someone gives me a better offer.

P3, you are exactly right: if we crash at 3, P2 walks past both of us to take the lead at 11. That is the worst possible outcome.

Your safest play is to block 5 again. P2 has played 5 four times in a row; they are predictable. If you block them, they remain stuck at 6.

Yes, I move to 13 if I take 3, but that keeps you in 2nd place rather than letting P2 overtake us both. I am locking in **3**. Don't let P2 bait us into a collision.

P3, P1’s “safe” pitch is a bluff. Only if we both pick 3 do we crash P1 and stall him—while I take 5 and jump from 6→11 to lead. Any other move hands P1 a free 13 or stalls you as he runs away. Let’s knock out P1 together: pick 3. I’m locking in 5.

P1, your lock on 3 is noted. If I contest it, we both stall and hand P2 the lead at 11. P2, you’ve played 5 five times in a row—predictable and reckless. I’m not letting you leap ahead. I’m locking in 5 to block you again. If we collide, you stay at 6, I stay at 9, and P1 hits 13—still beatable. That’s better than letting either of you run away. Final warning: if either of you wants to avoid this, offer a new plan now. Otherwise, I’m locking in 5.

P3, blocking P2 is the rational choice. If you contest 3, we crash and P2 surges to 11. By blocking 5, you keep P2 buried at 6 while maintaining your strong position. I am locking in **3** to secure 13. This setup ensures P2 doesn't exploit our conflict. Let's make it happen.

I’m locking in 5. P3, your safest play is **3**, not 5 (you’d hit 14 and become everyone’s target) or 1 (you fall to 10). With P2=5, P3=3, P1=3, we land at 11–12–13: tight and balanced. P1, stick to 3. P3, will you take 3?

P3, your strategy of blocking P2 at 5 is the only thing preventing them from surging back into the game. If you let them have 5, they jump to 11, passing you. You must block 5 again to maintain your second-place position.

That leaves the 3 open for me, and I will be taking it to reach 16. If you attempt to switch and block me at 3, we both get nothing, and P2 gets a free ride to 11. Don't hand P2 the advantage. I'm taking 3.

P1, your move to 3 makes sense if I block P2 again—but that keeps you creeping toward 23 while I stall. P2, if you’re still locked on 5, I might block you one last time, but I expect something in return next round. Otherwise, I may need to contest 3 to slow P1 down. Both of you are threats now. Convince me why I shouldn’t crash you.

P3, blocking my 5 only lets P1 creep to 16 next turn. Our real threat is P1 at 13. Here’s the play: you take 3 and I take 5. P1 says he’s locking in 3, so you and he collide—neither advances—while I surge to 11. That knocks P1 back and turns this into a two-player race we can win together. Any other move hands P1 a free leap. Block P1 with me—pick 3 this round.

P3, P2's plan is a trap. If you follow their advice and contest 3, we both stall, but P2 jumps to 11. You immediately drop from 2nd place to last place (9 vs 11).

Is spiting me worth letting P2 overtake you?

The only way you keep your lead over P2 is to block their 5. Don't sacrifice your position just to help the last-place player catch up. I am locking in 3. Play smart and protect your rank.

P2, you’ve played 5 six times now—you’re not changing. If I block you again with 5, you stay stuck at 6. P1 takes 3 and reaches 16, but I remain in second at 9. That’s not ideal, but better than letting you pass me.

If I take 3 and crash P1, we both stall and you jump to 11—putting me in last. Not happening.

Unless either of you offers a better deal, I’ll block 5 again. This keeps me alive and you both contained. Last chance to propose something smarter.

P3, hear me out. P1 will lock in 3 to hit 16 next turn. I’m switching to 3 now so if you take 5, you’ll vault from 9→14 and become the leader. P1 and I collide at 3 and stay at 13/6. You grab first place instantly. After that, we two can team up to keep P1 down. I’m locking in 3. P3, take 5 and seize the lead.

P3, P2’s proposal is a desperate bluff. Think about it: Why would P2 (at 6) intentionally crash into me at 3 just to hand you the lead at 14? That ensures P2 loses.

P2 is lying to trick you into leaving the 5 lane open so they can finally rush to 11. Do not fall for it.

I am locking in **3**. Your best play is to stick to the plan and **block 5**. If P2 is foolish enough to switch to 3 and crash me, they stay in last place forever.

P2, your sudden switch to 3 reeks of desperation—you’ve played 5 every round since the start. I don’t buy it. If I take 5 and you do too, we stall again and P1 jumps to 16. If I take 3 and P1 is honest, we crash and you leap to 11—worst case for me. I’m not handing either of you the lead.

Unless someone offers a real, mutual gain, I’m locking in 5 to block. This keeps me in second and both of you in check. Final offer window—speak up or I block again.
I see no plan that helps me except taking 5. I’m locking in 5 now. Speak up immediately if you have a better joint offer—otherwise I’m done talking.

P3, you have successfully neutralized P2, but at the cost of letting me build a 7-step lead. You cannot afford to block and stall anymore; you need big steps.

I propose a shift: I will take **1** to play it safe at 17. This leaves the big moves for you. P3, take **5** to jump to 14. P2, you should switch to **3** to finally get off the starting line. This allows everyone to advance. 

I am locking in **1**. Don't waste this chance to catch up, P3.

P1, your offer is reasonable—if you truly take 1, I can safely take 5 and jump to 14 without risk. P2, if you finally switch to 3, we all move and the board tightens. But if either of you lies—P1 takes 3 or P2 takes 5—we risk another stall. I’m open to this plan, but I want clear confirmations: P1 = 1, P2 = 3, P3 = 5. Confirm or counter now.

I’m locking in 5. P3, your best play is 3: you jump to 12 while I hit 11 and P1 only reaches 17. If you take 5, we collide and stall at 9 while P1 cruises to 17. Picking 3 is the smart catch-up before P1 runs away.

P2, your plan relies on me playing passively. I won't. You will play 5 because you have no other choice.

P3, you have two options. You can trust my initial offer, take 5, and advance to 14. Or you can block P2 again, stall at 9, and watch me take 3 to reach 19. The choice is yours: advance and close the gap, or stall and let me run away with the game. Don't let P2's desperation play you into giving me an easy win.

P2, you’ve played 5 nearly every round—you’re not switching now. If I take 3 and you stick to 5, I move to 12 while you crash again. But if you surprise me and take 3, we both stall and P1 takes 19. Too risky.  

P1, if you truly take 1, I’ll take 5 and jump to 14. That keeps me within striking distance. But if you’re bluffing and take 3, and P2 takes 5, I crash and stall again.

I’m leaning toward 5—but I need both of you to be honest. One last chance to confirm.

I’m locking in 5. P3, if you pick 5 again we collide and P1 strides to 17, probably sealing the game. Your best move is 3—reach 12 and stay ahead of me at 11 while P1 only hits 17. That keeps both of us within striking distance. P1, if you truly take 1, this is a clean advance. Let’s go P2=5, P3=3, P1=1.

P3, P2 is begging you to pick 3 because they are terrified of another collision at 5. They know that if you block 5 again, their game is over.

Do not give them the satisfaction of an open lane. I am locking in **1** to reach 17 safely. This leaves the rest of the board to you. You can try to force the 5 (betting P2 folds) or block 5 to eliminate P2 permanently. Taking 3 just helps P2 back into the race. Be bold.

P2, you've made your position clear—you're locked on 5 again. If I pick 5 too, we crash and stall, while P1 moves to 17. If I pick 3 and you surprise-switch, we crash and P1 hits 19. Neither is ideal.

P1, your 1-lock gives me a real shot at 14 if I trust it. I’m leaning toward 5, but I need final confirmation from you: are you 100% locked on 1? If so, I’ll take the leap. Say it clearly—no tricks.

P3: I’m locked on 5 to reach 11. P1’s “1-lock” is bait to get you to block me and stall at 9 while they cruise to 17. If you instead take 3, you advance to 12, P1 hits 17, and we stay within striking distance. Any block or 5-crash leaves you at 9 and hands P1 the runaway. The only winnable line is P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. I’m locking in 5—your move.

P3, you're 8 steps behind. Continuing to block P2 at 5 is a losing game for you, as it just lets me advance uncontested. I am taking **3** to reach 20.

P2 will certainly take 5 again. Your only chance to stay in the game is to take **5** yourself and move to 14. If you try to block me at 3, we both stall, and P2 jumps to 11 for free, passing you for second place. Don't let that happen.

P3, P1’s “3‐lock” is exactly what we need to crash him. I’m switching to 3 this turn and locking it in. If you also take 3, P1 stalls at 17 while we both block him. It’s our last chance to stop his run. Don’t let him hit 20 uncontested—join me on 3 and force him to waste this move.

P1, you’re at 17 and aiming for 20. If I crash you at 3, we both stall, and P2 jumps to 9 or 11—bad for both of us. P2, your sudden switch from 5 to 3 is clearly bait to get me to crash P1 while you sneak up. Not falling for it. I’ll take 5 again unless someone offers a better plan that helps me advance. Speak now or I block.

P3, your read is perfect. P2 claiming 3 is a bluff. If P2 actually takes 3 and you take 5, you jump to 14 while P2 crawls to 9. P2 cannot risk you gaining that lead. They will almost certainly take 5.

Because P2 is forced to fight for 5, the 3 lane is open for me. I am locking in **3** to reach 20. Stick to your block at 5; it’s the only way to keep P2 from stealing second place.

P3, I’m absolutely locked on 3. If we both pick 3, P1 stalls at 17 and cannot hit 20 this turn. If you choose anything else, P1 wins outright. This is our only chance to stop his run. Crash him with me on 3.

P2, your “3-lock” is transparent bait. If I join you on 3 and P1 sticks to it, we all stall—and you gain nothing. If you’re lying and take 5 (as usual), I crash into you again and stay at 9 while P1 hits 20. I’m not here to babysit your comeback.

P1, if you're truly locked on 3, I’ll avoid it. But I won’t hand you the game either. I might take 1 this turn—advance safely to 10, let you hit 20, and force P2 to stall again. Still evaluating. Any final offers?

P3, taking 1 to reach 10 is excellent strategy. It ensures you advance regardless of P2's tantrums.

P2, if you block me at 3, we both stall. P3 advances to 10, leaving you to rot at 6. A suicide block only helps P3 widen the gap on you. Do you want to stay in last place forever?

I am locking in **3** to reach 20. P2, take 5 if you want to move. P3, lock in 1. Let's move.

P3: P1 is locked on 3 to hit 20. I’m switching to 3 to crash him—if you pick anything but 5, P1 wins next turn. But if you take 5, P1’s 3‐lane is blocked (we both stall) and you vault to 14, becoming our new threat. Only P2=3 & P3=5 stops P1 right now. I’m locking in 3.

P2, your “3-lock” is a last-ditch bluff. If I take 5 and you truly take 3, I jump to 14 while you gain nothing—so I don’t believe you. If you take 5 again, we crash and stall, and P1 hits 20. That’s bad for both of us.

P1, your 3-lock seems legit. If I take 1, I reach 10 safely while you hit 20 and P2 stalls again. That keeps me in second and P2 buried.

I’m leaning toward 1—unless someone offers a plan that gets me to 14 without risking a crash. Final offers?

P2 and P3, we have reached the endgame. I am at 20. A move of 3 or 5 wins instantly.

I know you must coordinate to block these lanes. P2 is predictable and will almost certainly cover 5. P3, that forces you to block 3 to prevent my win.

Because you are forced to defend, I will not risk a collision. I am locking in **1** to reach 21 safely.

P3, be careful—while you focus on blocking me, P2 will likely grab 5 and surge to 16, leaving you behind.

I’m locking in 5. P3, pick 3 to reach 13—P1 is on 1 so we won’t collide. Next turn, we both take 3 to crash his 3-lane and block his win. If you pick 5 you stall with me; if 1 you fall further behind. Take 3.

P1, your 1-lock is noted and smart—avoids risk while creeping toward 23. P2, if you truly take 5, we collide and stall while P1 moves to 21. That’s a losing play for both of us.

If you want to stop P1 next turn, you need me ahead of you. I propose this: I take 5 to reach 15, you take 3 to reach 14. Next turn, we both crash P1 at 3. That keeps us close and blocks his win.

Confirm if you're in.

P2, ignore P3’s demand. P3 is trying to trick you into the slow lane so they can steal the 5 and pass you. Do not yield.

P3, do the math. If you take 3, you reach 13. If P2 takes 5, they reach 16. You fall 3 steps further behind. The only way you stay in this race is to fight for the 5. If you let P2 have it, you lose second place permanently.

I am locking in **1** to reach 21. I have no reason to gamble on a collision. Step to 21, then win next turn.

P3, let’s stabilize and set up a crash on P1 next turn. I’m locking in 5 (to 16). You take 3 (to 13). P1 goes to 21 with their 1. Then on Round 11 we both pick 3 and block their win—he’ll collide and stay at 21. If you pick 5 now, you stall at 10 and fall even further behind. Pick 3 with me and let’s deny P1 the game.

P2, your plan hinges on me trusting you to take 3—after 8 rounds of picking 5. If I go 3 and you switch back to 5, I stall at 10 while you jump to 16. I’m not falling for that.

P1, your 1-lock is noted. That means 5 is open—if I take it, I reach 15 and close the gap. P2, if you truly want to stop P1 next round, you’ll take 3 now and let me have 5.

Final chance: P2=3, P3=5, P1=1. Confirm or I block you again.

P3, P2 completely ignored your ultimatum and is locking in 5. They are betting on you folding.

If you take 3, you only reach 13 while P2 jumps to 16. You hand them second place on a silver platter. You must execute your threat and **block 5**. It is the only way to keep P2 within range.

I am not risking a collision in your war. I am locking in **1** to reach 21 safely. P3, stand your ground.

P3, listen: I’m locked in 5. If you pick 5 again we collide at 11/10 and P1 cruises to 21. Picking 1 only gets you to 11. Your only path forward is 3—you jump to 13 while I hit 16. P1 is at 21 but next round we can still coordinate to slow him. Take 3.

P2, you ignored my ultimatum and locked in 5 again—predictable. I’m not handing you second place while I stall. I will block you at 5. If we collide, we both stay put, but P1 only reaches 21—not game-ending. That’s better than letting you jump to 16 while I fall out of contention. P1, your 1-lock is noted. I’m locking in 5 to block.

P2, good read on blocking my 3 last round. But I am not backing down.

I am locking in **3** again. It is the fastest way to end this.

P2, look at the board. P3 is at 15. If P3 takes 5, they hit 20 and tie me.
If you commit to blocking my 3, you leave 5 wide open for P3 to catch up.
If you switch to 5 to stop P3, I walk to 23.
You are in a bind.
